security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The scanner incorrectly identified Tailwind CSS directives (@apply, @layer, @utility, @variant) as shell backticks, and misinterpreted YAML frontmatter as weak cryptographic patterns. The skill is a legitimate component design guide containing only documentation and CSS styling instructions.

medium_findings.title: False Positive: Tailwind CSS Directives Misidentified as Shell Backticks
medium_findings.description: The static scanner flagged Tailwind CSS directives (@apply, @layer, @utility, @variant) as Ruby/shell backtick execution. These are legitimate CSS preprocessing directives, not code execution patterns.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Direct examination of SKILL.md confirms only Tailwind CSS directives are present, not shell or Ruby backtick syntax

medium_findings.title: False Positive: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm Detection
medium_findings.description: The static scanner flagged YAML frontmatter as weak cryptographic patterns. The file is a markdown documentation file with no cryptographic code.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: SKILL.md contains only component design documentation, not cryptographic algorithms or sensitive operations

content.value_statement: Developers need consistent, maintainable UI components but lack guidance on project conventions. This skill provides clear rules for designing components using Tailwind CSS, including file organization, styling patterns, and project structure.
actual_capabilities: Creates separate CSS files for component styling
Applies Tailwind CSS @apply directives for consistent styling
Organizes styles using @layer components for proper cascade
Follows project conventions for component file placement
limitations: Does not generate full component code including TypeScript or React
Focuses on Tailwind CSS, not other styling approaches

best_practices: Use separate CSS files for each component to maintain separation of concerns and enable better caching
Organize styles within @layer components to ensure proper cascade order and prevent conflicts
Reference Tailwind v4 documentation for context-specific patterns before implementing custom solutions
anti_patterns: Avoid mixing inline styles with Tailwind utility classes as it breaks the utility-first pattern
Do not modify files in src/components/ui as these are reserved for shared UI library components
Avoid creating monolithic CSS files that combine multiple unrelated component styles

faq.question: What is the purpose of @layer components in Tailwind CSS?
faq.answer: The @layer components directive tells Tailwind to add styles to the components layer. This ensures proper cascade order, with base styles at the bottom, components in the middle, and utilities on top.

faq.question: How do @utility and @variant directives differ?
faq.answer: @utility creates custom utility classes like custom spacing or sizing. @variant creates custom state variants like hover:, focus:, or dark: for existing utilities.

faq.question: Where should new components be placed?
faq.answer: Create new components in the src/components root directory. Never modify files in src/components/ui as these are reserved for shared UI library components.

faq.question: Should I use nested classes for child elements?
faq.answer: Yes, use nested classes within @layer components for styling parent and child elements together. This keeps related styles co-located and easier to maintain.

faq.question: What Tailwind v4 documentation should I reference?
faq.answer: Refer to the context files for theme variables, custom styles, functions and directives, detecting classes in source files, and the upgrade guide for Tailwind v4 specific patterns.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with CSS frameworks other than Tailwind?
faq.answer: No, this skill is specifically designed for Tailwind CSS. The @apply, @layer, @utility, and @variant directives are Tailwind-specific features.
